title.value: Validation of Vigilance Decline Capability in A Simulated Test Environment: A Preliminary Step Towards Neuroadaptive Control
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned at the beginning and throughout the document.
title.quote: Validation of Vigilance Decline Capability in A Simulated Test Environment: A Preliminary Step Towards Neuroadaptive Control

extractions.description: This paper investigates the capability of a simulated test environment to induce vigilance decline, setting the stage for developing neuroadaptive control systems. The study employs various physiological and self-report measures to assess vigilance levels.

type.justification: The paper is based on an experimental study with participants to measure vigilance decline using various tools, which implies an empirical research type.
type.quote: We used the Karolinska Sleepiness Scale (KSS), Stanford Sleepiness Scale (SSS), Psychomotor Vigilance Task (PVT), along with neurophysiological specialized equipment.

name.justification: The paper focuses on understanding and adapting to cognitive states, which is a central theme in Neuroergonomics and Cognitive Engineering.
Since the study involves manipulation and measurement of cognitive states and tasks, it falls under Cognitive Engineering.
The study assesses human performance and safety in simulated driving tasks, aligning it with Human Factors and Ergonomics.
name.quote: Vigilance, Simulated driving, Karolinska sleepiness scale, Stanford sleepiness scale, Psychomotor vigilance task, Driving behaviour, Driving safety, Adaptive control, Neuroadaptive technologies

name.justification: The paper uses neurophysiological and psychophysiological measures to assess vigilance, fitting into the study of psychophysiology.
name.quote: measures such as heart rate variability (HRV) and electrodermal activity sensors offer valuable insights into autonomic nervous system responses and physiological arousal
